coredata.dc:title: Cold-pressing PEO/LAGP composite electrolyte for integrated all-solid-state lithium metal battery

coredata.dc:description: Polyethylene-oxide (PEO)-based electrolyte is one of the most promising solid electrolytes due to its outstanding safety and excellent flexibility. However, the most common method to fabricate PEO-based electrolyte is casting, which requires intensive use of toxic organic solvent. Besides, the agglomeration of filler in the composite electrolyte fabricated by casting limits further enhancement of ionic conductivity. In this work, we provide a facile solvent-free cold-pressing method to prepare well-dispersed LAGP @ PEO composite solid-state electrolyte. The ionic conductivity of LAGP @ PEO composite electrolyte can reach about 4.4 × 10− 5 S cm− 1 at room temperature which is nearly one order of magnitude higher than that of the casting one (3.3 × 10− 6 S cm− 1). The integrated all-solid-state batteries display excellent cycling stability and good rate performance at 50 °C. Our work provides a facile solvent-free cold-pressing method to fabricate polymer-based composite electrolyte with well-dispersed filler for all-solid-state batteries.

xocs:item-toc-entry.xocs:item-toc-section-title: Preparation of LAGP@PEO composite electrolyte by casting (L@PCE-C)
Preparation of LAGP@PEO composite electrolyte by cold-pressing (L@PCE-CP)

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: a), b) optical photograph and c) diagram of electrolyte by cold pressing.

The impedance spectra of L@PCE-C a) and L@PCE-CP b) composite solid electrolytes with different LAGP contents. Ionic conductivity of L@ PCE-C c) and L@ PCE-CP d) at 25 °C; e) temperature dependent ionic conductivity of L@PCE-CP; f) LSV profile of L@PCE-CP with 20 wt% LAGP.
a) XRD patterns of LAGP, PEO, L@PCE-CP and L@PCE-C; b) TGA profiles of 20% L@PCE-CP and L@PCE-C; SEM images of c) L@PCE-CP and d) L@PCE-C.

(a) Cycling performances of Li/L@PCE-CP/LFP at 0.1 C and 50 °C using PL and PPL as cathode binder; (b) voltage-time profiles of symmetric cell with and without Li protective layer at 0.05 mA cm− 2 and 50 °C.
a) Cycle performance and b) rate performance of LFP/L@PCE-CP/Li ASSBs at 0.1 C and 50 °C.

head.ce:title: Cold-pressing PEO/LAGP composite electrolyte for integrated all-solid-state lithium metal battery

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Research Center for Carbon Nanomaterials, Key Laboratory for Liquid-Solid Structural Evolution & Processing of Materials (Ministry of Education), School of Materials Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan 250061, China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: Key Laboratory for Liquid-Solid Structural Evolution & Processing of Materials (Ministry of Education)
School of Materials Science and Engineering

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: Research Center for Carbon Nanomaterials, Key Laboratory for Liquid-Solid Structural Evolution & Processing of Materials (Ministry of Education), School of Materials Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan 250061, China

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Polyethylene-oxide (PEO)-based electrolyte is one of the most promising solid electrolytes due to its outstanding safety and excellent flexibility. However, the most common method to fabricate PEO-based electrolyte is casting, which requires intensive use of toxic organic solvent. Besides, the agglomeration of filler in the composite electrolyte fabricated by casting limits further enhancement of ionic conductivity. In this work, we provide a facile solvent-free cold-pressing method to prepare well-dispersed LAGP @ PEO composite solid-state electrolyte. The ionic conductivity of LAGP @ PEO composite electrolyte can reach about 4.4 × 10− 5 S cm− 1 at room temperature which is nearly one order of magnitude higher than that of the casting one (3.3 × 10− 6 S cm− 1). The integrated all-solid-state batteries display excellent cycling stability and good rate performance at 50 °C. Our work provides a facile solvent-free cold-pressing method to fabricate polymer-based composite electrolyte with well-dispersed filler for all-solid-state batteries.

ce:section.ce:para: Lithium (Li)-ion batteries have been widely used in electronic devices, but their energy density need to be further improved to meet the ever-increasing demand for high-energy batteries in modern society [1–4]. Li metal has been extensively considered as the most promising anode for next-generation rechargeable batteries due to its high theoretical specific capacity of 3860 mAh g−1 and lowest electrode potential (−3.040 V vs. standard hydrogen electrode) [5–8]. However, metallic Li is unstable in traditional organic liquid electrolyte and can continuously react with electrolyte, which lead to rapid consumption of both electrolyte and Li metal [9]. In addition, the undesired Li dendrite growth may cause internal short and further lead to fire or even explosion in traditional Li-ion batteries with liquid electrolyte [10]. The low safety and cycling instability caused by random detrimental dendrite or mossy Li growth hinder the application of Li-metal-based batteries with organic liquid electrolyte. Exploring solid state electrolytes (SSEs) is a promising solution to suppress Li dendrite and enhance safety [11,12].

Over the past years, various kinds of SSEs such as inorganic ceramic electrolyte, organic polymer electrolyte and composite electrolyte have been employed in all-solid-state Li batteries (ASSLBs) [13]. Among them, PEO-based electrolyte is one of the most promising electrolyte due to its ability of good solubility for Li-salts, high mechanical properties and good interfacial contact with electrodes [14]. The mechanism of Li-ion transport in PEO-based solid electrolyte has been studied before. The Li-ions form coordination bonds with the ether oxygen atoms on the segmental chain of PEO. With the processes of continuously forming/breaking LiO coordination bonds, Li-ions transport in electrolyte, and the continuous segmental rearrangement result in a long-range displacement of Li-ions as Fig. S1 [15,16]. Pristine PEO are semi-crystalline polymer. Crystalline region hinders the motion of segmental PEO chain, therefore, pristine PEO shows low ionic conductivity (lower than 10− 6 S cm− 1 at room temperature) [16,17]. Since the first work reported by Wright [15], many tactics have been employed to enhance the ion conductivity of PEO [18,19]. Adding inorganic ceramic electrolyte particles to form composite electrolyte is a promising method [20]. Li1.5Al0.5Ge1.5(PO4)3 (LAGP) inorganic Li+-conducting solid state electrolyte material is considered as a promising filler due to the high Li+ conductivity(~10− 4 S cm− 1), air-stability, wide applicable temperature ranges and low cost [21–24].

Currently, most composite solid electrolytes are fabricated by casting or hot-pressing [25–29]. The casting method adopts toxic organic solvent like tetrahydrofuran, dimethylformamide or acetonitrile, etc. Besides, the agglomeration of filler in the composite electrolyte fabricated by casting hinders further enhancement of its ionic conductivity. While, the hot-pressing needs much energy to provide a long-time heat treatment. Besides, due to the large interface resistance and low ionic conductivity, the batteries adopting the PEO-based electrolytes need to be operated at above 60 °C [30]. It is necessary to achieve the high ionic conductivity of electrolyte and low resistance interface in all-solid-state batteries. Herein, facile solvent-free cold-pressing method is applied to fabricate the composite electrolyte. This composite electrolyte exhibits a decomposition potential of 5.1 V at 50 °C. We also compared the ionic conductivity of the composite electrolytes fabricated by casting (donated as L@PCE-C) and the one by cold-pressing (labeled as L@PCE-CP). With 20 wt% LAGP in PEO, the ionic conductivity of L@PCE-CP can reach about 4.4 × 10− 5 S cm− 1 at room temperature, which is much higher than that of L@PCE-C (3.3 × 10− 6 S cm− 1). What's more, electrodes were also modified to further improve the performance of batteries. With such composite polymer electrolyte and modified electrodes, an integrated all-solid state Li metal battery of LFP/composite polymer electrolyte/Li exhibits a high cycling stability with 92% specific capacity retention ratio after 100 cycles at 0.1 C (50 °C). The above results indicate the simple solvent-free cold-pressing method can be well applied in fabrication of polymer-based composite electrolyte.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Preparation of LAGP@PEO composite electrolyte by casting (L@PCE-C)
ce:section.ce:para: PEO (MW = 600,000, Sigma-Aldrich) and LiTFSI (99.9%, Aladdin) were vacuum-dried before use. PEO and LiTFSI were dissolved in an appropriate amount of acetonitrile at a mole ratio of EO:Li = 8:1 [31,32] in an argon-filled glovebox (H2O, O2 <0.01 ppm). After stirring at 60 °C for 12 h, the mixture turned into homogeneous solution. Then LAGP with different weight ratios (10, 20, 50 and 80 wt% of PEO) were added into the uniform solution. After another magnetic stirring for 12 h, a suspension was obtained. Next, the dispersed mixture was poured into polyfluortetraethylene (PTFE) module and dried at room temperature for 48 h, followed by further drying at 60 °C for 12 h to remove residual solvent. Finally, uniform composite solid state electrolyte membranes were obtained and cut into the desired shape and size.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Preparation of LAGP@PEO composite electrolyte by cold-pressing (L@PCE-CP)
ce:section.ce:para: PEO (MW = 600,000) and LiTFSI (99.9%) were mixed by the mole ratio of EO:Li = 8:1, followed by grinding with a mortar for 10 min in a glovebox filled with argon. After that, 10, 20, 50 and 80 wt% LAGP were respectively added into the mixture followed by further grinding for 10 min. Then the obtained mixture was transferred into a stainless-steel mold and pressed under a pressure of 10 MPa to get the bendable solid electrolyte membrane. The size and shape can be obtained by using different molds (Fig. 1 ).

X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the composite electrolyte, LAGP, and PEO were recorded by an X-ray diffractometer (Bruker D8 Advance, Germany) using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54 Å) in an angular range of 10°-90° (2θ). The morphology was characterized by a scanning electron microscope (Phenom Pro). The ionic conductivity of solid electrolytes at different temperatures was measured by an electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) in a symmetrical stainless-steel/electrolyte/stainless-steel cell with an AC amplitude of 10 mV. The EIS plots were obtained in a frequency range from 1 MHz to 0.1 Hz within a temperature range of 25 to 60 °C on Metrohm-Autolab B.V. The electrochemical stability of the composite solid electrolyte was investigated via linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) which was applied to a cell with a stainless-steel plate as working electrode and Li metal as the counter and reference electrode. The applied potential ranges from 3 to 6 V at a scanning rate of 0.1 mV s− 1. The Li ion transference numbers were measured at 25 °C by electrochemical workstation. A constant voltage (10 mV) was applied until Li/electrolyte/Li cell reached a stable current value. Lithium transference number is calculated using the following equation:
(1)

=
I ss
∆ V −

I 0
∆ V −
I ss
R ss
where ∆V is the applied constant voltage, I0 is the initial current, Iss is the steady-state current, Rss and R0 are the interfacial resistances after and before the polarization, respectively.

The cathode of the all-solid-state batteries (ASSBs) was prepared by adding 80 wt% LFP, 10 wt% binder, and 10 wt% super p in NMP to obtain a uniform slurry, followed by coating it on the aluminum current collector and drying at 70 °C for 24 h in a vacuum oven. In addition, to improve the interfacial contact between electrolyte and cathode as well as the ionic transportation among active material particles, PEO, PVDF and LiClO4 (PEO:PVDF:LiClO4 = 25:30:14 in weight ratio) were added into an appropriate amount of NMP and further stirred at 70 °C for 2 h to form the advanced binder solution. The loading of active mass in LFP cathode is about 1.1 mg/cm2. For the Li metal anode, Li foil was cut into a round sheet and pressed on a stainless-steel current collector. Then a thin layer of PEO-500000 (LiTFSI) was coated on the surface by drop-casting a 7 wt% PEO-500000 (LiTFSI)/THF (EO:Li = 8:1) solution followed by drying at 50 °C. ASSBs with Li/LAGP@PEO/LFP were assembled into 2032 coin-type cells without using any other liquid electrolyte in an argon-filled glovebox.

The symmetric Li/CPE/Li cells were assembled and cycled at a current density of 0.05 mA cm− 2 by using a multichannel battery tester (LAND 2001A Battery Testing System). The cycle performance tests of all-solid-state LFP/CPE/Li batteries were carried out at 50 °C between 2.8 and 4.0 V at 0.1 C。.

The ionic conductivity (σ) is calculated by the following equation [33]:
(2)
σ =
L RS
where S is the area of electrolyte, L the thickness of electrolyte. R is obtained by EIS measurement with symmetric cell of the electrolyte sandwiched by two stainless steel electrodes. The Nyquist plots of L@PCE-C and L@PCE-CP for evaluating the Li-ion conductivity are shown in Fig. 2a and b. In the Nyquist plots, the impedance spectra of the cells are comprised of one semicircles and one inclined line. The small intercept corresponds to the electrolyte resistance (RΩ). The depressed semicircle is related to the charge-transfer resistance (Rct) and the double-layer capacitance (Cd), and the inclined line at low frequencies represents the Warburg impedance due to the diffusion of lithium ions in the electrode (Zw). The equivalent circuit model is shown in the inset of Fig. 2a and b. The calculated room-temperature Li-ion conductivities of L@PCE-CP are much higher than those of L@PCE-C (Fig. 2c and d). The highest conductivity of about 4.4 × 10− 5 S cm− 1 presents to L@PCE-CP with 20 wt% LAGP, which is nearly one order of magnitude higher than the value of 3.3 × 10− 6 S cm− 1 for L@PCE-C (20 wt% LAGP). The linear relationship between Li-ion conductivity and temperature displayed in Fig. 2e conforms to the Arrhenius equation [34]. Observing electrolyte has an inflection point at about 50 °C, which is consistent with other reports [35]. Below 50 °C, the composite electrolyte is hemi crystalline state, which hinders the transport of Li-ions, showing a low ionic conductivity. However, the ionic conductivity significantly increases at high temperature due to the frequently movement of PEO segment in an amorphous state. Besides, the Li ion transference number (tLi+) was test by DC polarization and AC electrochemical impedance spectroscopy before and after polarization. The results were presented in Fig. S6, the calculated tLi+ was 0.308. Moreover, linear scanning voltammetry (LSV) was carried out to evaluate the electrochemical stability window of 20% LAGP @ PEO composite electrolyte (donated as 20% L@PCE). Fig. 2f presents that there is no obvious decomposition before 5.1 V (vs. Li+/Li) in the composite electrolyte fabricated by cold-pressing at 50 °C. This result shows that L@PCE-CP exhibits excellent electrochemical stability, which can be applied to high-potential Li batteries. 20% L@PCE are chosen for further study as the electrolyte with much improved ionic conductivity fabricated by cold pressing.

XRD patterns of PEO-based composite solid electrolyte are shown Fig. 3a, and the added amount was further determined to be 20 wt% by TGA (Fig. 3b). Besides, three-stage degradation process was observed in TGA curves. Below 100 °C, the evaporation of water caused the first slight weight loss. The second significant weight drop was due to the decomposition of PEO. After that, the third subsequent degradation ascribe to the decomposition of LiTFSI [36]. Moreover, TGA of 10%, 50%, 80% L@CPE-C and L@CPE-CP (Figs. S2, S3, S4) were also tested to ensure desired amount of LAGP was mixed into PEO. 20% L@PCE composites fabricated by different methods were characterized by SEM to observe the dispersity of LAGP particles in composite electrolyte. The particles are uniformly distributed in L@PCE-CP as shown in Fig. 3c, while LAGP particles in L@PCE-C are easier to agglomerate into particle clusters in Fig. 3d. The uniform distribution of inorganic filler may be the reason why the electrolyte fabricated by cold-pressing shows higher ionic conductivity and excellent electrochemical stability. On one hand, there is a process of drying at casting. During organic solvent volatilization, fillers will settle, which is beneficial to the agglomeration of fillers. On the other hand, due to the hydrophilic of inorganic fillers, the inorganic fillers tend to aggregation in organic solvent [37]. The distribution of LAGP particles in 10%, 50%, 80% L@CPE-C and L@CPE-CP were also analyzed in Fig. S4. With the increase of LAGP content, the more aggregation of LAGP particles can be found.

Electrodes were also modified to further improve the performance of batteries. The active material is apt to exfoliate from Al foil during continual charge and discharge process, which leads to poor cycling stability [38]. In order to increase the adhesion properties, PEO-PVDF-based binder has been adopted in LiFePO4 (LFP) cathode. Furthermore, anode was also modified by coating a thin protective film on Li anode to avoid the reaction between Li and LAGP. As shown in Fig. 4a, the batteries with cathode adopting PPL (PEO-PVDF-Li-salt) as binder exhibit a better cycling stability than those using PL (PEO-Li-Salt). The specific capacity retention ratio of batteries using PPL (95.5%) is higher than that using PL (87.5%) after 40 cycles. It is well-known that crystallization degree of binder plays an important role in controlling the properties of batteries. Amorphous structure can help to improve the adhesion properties and electrochemical performance. -C-O- and -CF in the structures of PEO and PVDF can lead to excellent interactions between these two polar macromolecules, which suppress the crystallization of these two semi-crystalline polymers. Compared with traditional semi-crystalline polymer binder (PL) used in solid-state batteries, PPL binder with abundant amorphous structures can result in enhanced adhesion properties and higher ionic conductivity [38]. As a result, the active material exhibits more stable contact with current collector, and the batteries with cathode using PPL binder have a higher specific capacity retention.

As illustrated in Fig. 4b, symmetric cells were galvanostatically charged and discharged for a period of 1 h under a current density of 0.05 mA cm− 2 at 50 °C. After cycling for 1500 h, the voltage hysteresis of symmetric cell with a protective layer (50w-PEO-Li-salt) can still be stabilized at about 50 mV. It is well-known that Li is unstable when contacted with LAGP, the thin protective layer coated on Li can effectively avoid direct contact of Li with LAGP and thus reduce side reactions. Moreover, good contact performance brought by the protective layer contributes to a uniform Li plating/stripping. From the above points, symmetric cell with a protective layer shows much improved interfacial compatibility and cycling stability. On the contrary, voltage hysteresis is obviously increased for the cell composed of bare Li metal anodes due to the adverse interfacial reactions between Li and the exposed LAGP. The abrupt voltage drops (indicated by arrow in Fig. 4b) in the later cycling period are generally attributed to micro short circuit of the cell, which suggests undesired deposition of Li [39]. Hence, the Li dendrites can be effectively suppressed in the cell with advanced construction to some extent.

Fig. 5a shows the application of 20% LAGP @ PEO composite electrolyte fabricated by cold-pressing (L@PCE-CP) in all-solid-state batteries. The LFP/L@PCE-CP/Li batteries with modified electrodes were assembled in an argon-filled glovebox and cycled at 0.1 C at 50 °C. The initial discharge specific capacity of the battery is 143 mAh g− 1. After 100 cycles, the discharge specific capacity remains 135 mAh g− 1, which indicates an excellent cycling stability. Rate performance from 0.1 to 1.0 C at 50 °C of LFP/L@PCE-CP/Li batteries is displayed in Fig. 5b. The discharge specific capacity of LFP/L@PCE-CP/Li batteries is 135, 128, 100 and 50 mAh g− 1 at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5 and 1.0 C, respectively. After set back to 0.1 C, the specific capacity is 130 mAh g− 1. The results indicate the high ionic conductivity of L@PCE-CP and excellent stability of LFP/L@PCE-CP/Li batteries.

In summary, bendable LAGP @ PEO composite electrolyte with a high ionic conductivity at 25 °C has been fabricated by a facile solvent-free cold-pressing method. We also revealed that the PPL-based cathode has a better cycling stability than PL-based cathode. Integrated all-solid-state battery with an advanced construction of LFP (PEO-PVDF binder)/L@PCE-CP/(PEO-based film) Li was developed. In addition, the PEO in cathode, the flexible electrolyte and protective film of Li anode provide a valid buffer to the volume expansion and thus ensure a good interfacial contact during the charge and discharge process. The specific capacity of the all-solid-state batteries reaches 136 mAh g− 1 after 100 cycles at 0.1 C (50 °C), which indicates excellent cycling stability. All the results show that the cold-pressing is a simple, valid and environmentally friendly method to fabricate high performance PEO-based electrolyte and the integrated all-solid-state using the as fabricated electrolyte exhibits a promising performance.
